quiz.title: Class Attributes and Methods Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Class attributes and Class Methods

answers.comments: Yes! If our definition of an object is a bundle of code that contains data and behaviors, then an entire class itself qualifies as an object.
You might want to review the source/s for this question.
Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: What type of scope does a class attribute have?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Class attributes and Class Methods

answers.comments: Exactly! A class attribute is accessible to the whole class and is unique to the class itself.
Local scope is used to describe variables declared in a specific scope, such as in methods. They are only available within that scope.
Global variables are available everywhere.
Instance variables belong to specific instances/objects of a class and are declared with self.
answers.comments_html: Instance variables belong to specific instances/objects of a class and are declared with self.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code:

class MyClass:  
  @classmethod
  def class_method_name(cls):
    # some code

In this code sample, what does the keyword cls refer to?
questions.neutral_comments: Source/s:  Class attributes and Class Methods

answers.comments: Perfect! cls is being used inside the class itself, so it refers to the class.
answers.comments_html: Perfect! cls is being used inside the class itself, so it refers to the class.

answers.comments: Where is cls being used? Is it inside an instance method or inside the class?
answers.comments_html: Where is cls being used? Is it inside an instance method or inside the class?

answers.comments: Where is cls being used? Is it inside the class or just floating around in the file not nested in any other code?
answers.comments_html: Where is cls being used? Is it inside the class or just floating around in the file not nested in any other code?

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: What type of constant is defined within a class and is available to all instances of a particular class?

answers.comments: Amazing! Class constants have the same value no matter which instance is accessing it. It is a shared constant and is also accessible inside of class methods.
answers.comments_html:
Amazing! Class constants have the same value no matter which instance is
accessing it. It is a shared constant and is also accessible inside of class
methods.

answers.comments: A global constant would be available to all class instances, not just a single class. It would also be available to methods outside of classes, and, well, everywhere.
We don't usually declare constants inside of instance methods. What kind of constant might we need if we want all of the instances of a class to have access to the same value?
answers.comments_html:
We don't usually declare constants inside of instance methods. What kind of
constant might we need if we want all of the instances of a class to have
access to the same value?

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: To create a constant, what syntax should be used?

answers.comments: Exactly! All caps and snake case is the way to go. We'd also declare it outside of any methods.
answers.comments_html:
Exactly! All caps and snake case is the way to go. We'd also declare it outside
of any methods.

answers.comments: This is how we declare instance variables. You might want to review the source/s for this question.
answers.comments_html:
This is how we declare instance variables. You might want to review the source/s
for this question.

answers.comments: This is how we declare class variables. You might want to review the source/s for this question.
answers.comments_html:
This is how we declare class variables. You might want to review the source/s
for this question.

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code:

class Book:

  genres = []

  def __init__(self, title, author = "", page_count = 0):
    self.title = title
    self.author = author
    self.page_count = page_count


  def genre(self, genre):
    return GENRE

Every time a genre is added to a Book object, we want to store that genre in the class variable named genres. The code above doesn't currently do this. Select the code snippet that does.

answers.text: class Book: genres = [] def __init__(self, title, author = "", page_count = 0): self.title = title self.author = author self.page_count = page_count def genre(cls, genre): return cls.genres.append(genre)
answers.html:
class Book:

  genres = []

  def __init__(self, title, author = "", page_count = 0):
    self.title = title
    self.author = author
    self.page_count = page_count


  def genre(cls, genre):
    return cls.genres.append(genre)
answers.comments: Wow! Nailed it!! By calling cls.genres.append adding the genre to genres, we achieve exactly what we want.
answers.comments_html: Wow! Nailed it!! By calling cls.genres.append adding the genre to genres, we achieve exactly what we want.

answers.text: class Book: genres = [] def __init__(self, title, author = "", page_count = 0): self.title = title self.author = author self.page_count = page_count def genre(cls, genre): return genres.append(genre)
answers.html:
class Book:

  genres = []

  def __init__(self, title, author = "", page_count = 0):
    self.title = title
    self.author = author
    self.page_count = page_count


  def genre(cls, genre):
    return genres.append(genre)
answers.comments: This isn't actually adding the genre to genres. Is there something missing?
answers.comments_html: This isn't actually adding the genre to genres. Is there something missing?

answers.comments: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
